preserve.translation[0].definitions[0].d: to save something or someone from being harmed or destroyed
preserve.translation[0].definitions[0].e: We must encourage the planting of new trees and preserve our existing woodlands.
preserve.translation[0].definitions[1].d: to make something continue without changing
preserve.translation[0].definitions[1].e: the responsibility of the police to preserve the peace
Norma tried to preserve a normal family life in difficult circumstances.
preserve.translation[0].definitions[2].d: to store food for a long time after treating it so that it will not decay
preserve.translation[1].definitions[0].d: a substance made from boiling fruit or vegetables with sugar, salt, or vinegar
preserve.translation[1].definitions[1].d: an activity that is only suitable or allowed for a particular group of people
preserve.translation[1].definitions[1].e: Banking used to be a male preserve.
The civil service became the preserve of the educated middle class.
preserve.translation[1].definitions[2].d: an area of land or water that is kept for private hunting or fishing
